abstract.p: While the empirical validity of the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) of Sharpe (1964) is controversial, the conditional version of the CAPM is a simple but powerful tool to examine the time-varying properties of risk and returns. However, even leading textbooks offer a limited presentation of the methodology and supporting evidence of this model. In this paper, a well known strategy based on the book-to-market ratio provides the intuition and simplifies the mechanics of the conditional CAPM. Next, novel results across a large array of portfolios based on book-to-market, market capitalization and industries groups enable a more comprehensive discussion of the implications of the conditional CAPM in the classroom.
